FIFA World Cup.passage: The FIFA World Cup is an international football tournament contested by the men's national teams of the members of Fédération Internationale de Football Association (FIFA), the sport's global governing body. The tournament has been held every four years since the first edition in 1930, except for the years of the Second World War, with the exception of the 1942 and 1946 tournaments, which were held as a single tournament contested by national teams in South America. The tournament consists of several stages, including qualification, which takes place over the preceding three years, and the final tournament, which is held over a month in the host nation(s). The qualification process, which is conducted by the respective continental confederations, determines the participating teams, with the number of places allocated to each continent being based on the relative strength of the confederations' teams. The final tournament, which is held every four years, consists of several stages, including the group stage, knockout stage, and the final. The group stage, which is held in multiple venues across the host nation(s), involves the 32 teams being divided into eight groups of four teams each. Each team plays the other three teams in their group once, with the top two teams from each group advancing to the knockout stage. The knockout stage, which is held in multiple venues across the host nation(s), involves the remaining 16 teams being drawn into four sets of single-elimination matches. The winners of each match advance to the next round, with the final two teams playing the championship match to determine the winner of the tournament. The FIFA World Cup is the most prestigious association football tournament in the world, and the most widely viewed and followed sporting event in the world, exceeding even the Olympic Games.

The competition was first held in the 1992–93 season as the UEFA Champions League, but was previously known as the European Cup from 1955 to 1992. Wimbledon Championships.passage: Wimbledon Championships, also known simply as Wimbledon, is the oldest tennis tournament in the world, and is held annually in late June and early July at the All England Club in Wimbledon, London, United Kingdom. The tournament is considered the most prestigious event in the sport of tennis, and the winners of the men's and women's singles titles are widely regarded as the true champions of the sport. Ryder Cup.passage: The Ryder Cup is a biennial men's golf competition between teams from Europe and the United States. the United States.passage: The United States of America (USA), commonly referred to as the United States (U.S.) or America, is a federal republic composed of 50 states, a federal district, five major self-governing territories, and various possessions. At 3.8 million square miles (9.8 million km2), the United States is the world's third- or fourth-largest country by total area and slightly smaller than the entire continent of Europe's 3.9 million square miles (10.1 million km2). With a population of over 328 million people, the U.S. is the third most populous country in the world. The capital is Washington, D.C., and the largest city by population is New York City. Forty-eight states and the capital's federal district are contiguous and located in North America between Canada and Mexico. The state of Alaska is in the northwest corner of North America, bordered by Canada to the east and across the Bering Strait from Russia to the west. The state of Hawaii is an archipelago in the mid-Pacific Ocean. The U.S. territories are scattered around the Pacific Ocean and the Caribbean Sea, stretching across nine official time zones. The extremely diverse geography, climate, and wildlife of the United States make it one of the world's 17 megadiverse countries.

qae_pairs.question: What body of water is located to the southeast of the United States?
qae_pairs.explanation: The state of Hawaii is an archipelago in the mid-Pacific Ocean.

Samuel Ryder.passage: Samuel Ryder was an English businessman and golfer who founded the Ryder Cup competition. Born in St Albans, Hertfordshire, England, in 1858, Ryder was a successful businessman who made his fortune in the manufacturing industry. He was also an avid golfer and was a member of several golf clubs in the United Kingdom. In 1926, Ryder donated a trophy to be awarded to the winner of a golf competition between American and British professionals. The competition was first held in 1927 and was named the Ryder Cup in honor of its founder. The event has since become one of the most prestigious golf tournaments in the world, with teams from Europe and the United States competing every two years. Ryder was also a philanthropist and used his wealth to support various charitable causes. He established the Samuel Ryder Foundation, which provided financial support to a number of organizations, including hospitals, schools, and churches. Ryder died in 1936 at the age of 78 and was buried in St Albans. His legacy lives on through the Ryder Cup competition, which continues to be a highly anticipated event in the world of golf.
